The following answers to questions were circulated: National Road Safety Strategy: Cycling (Question No. 105) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13/2/02: (1) Is the Australia Cycling National Strategy examining the (a) benchmarking of bicycle use, (b) benchmarking of accident exposure and (c) benchmarking of bicycling facilities in Australia using international standards; if not, why not. (2) Has the National Strategy met its December 2000 objective to include cycling expertise in peak transport, recreation and other appropriate bodies; if not, why not. (3) Has the National Strategy met its January 2001 objective to make education about cycling available for pre, primary and secondary school aged students, consistent with curriculum frameworks; if not, why not. (4) What work has been done to enable the National Strategy to meet its June 2001 objectives to (a) improve the services and products delivered by the bicycle industry through the development of partnerships; (b) develop a generic policy that can be adapted by all local governments which outlines their role in creating pro-bicycle cultures and physical environments; (c) ensure that appropriate new and renovated public and private developments include end-of-trip facilities for cyclists consistent with national standards; (d) increase multi-nodal trips involving bicycles and public transport; (e) develop and implement a national public communication strategy to improve the awareness of all road users and path users to better share our roads and paths; (f) ensure that safety initiatives such as safety audits and identification of blackspots include consideration of cycling; and (g) develop and implement behavioural programs/initiatives relating to all road users which improve cyclist safety in areas such as motor vehicle speeds and helmets. (1) Responsibility for implementation of Australia Cycling, a National Strategy (the National Strategy) rests primarily with the State, Territory and Local Government authorities, which are best placed to determine local solutions and funding requirements. The Commonwealth provides the Secretariat to the Australian Bicycle Council (ABC), which is a body that was established to coordinate implementation of the National Strategy on behalf of all governments. The ABC commenced a study of cycling data and indicators in September 2001 under Strategy 5.2 of the National Strategy. The study seeks “to identify data requirements and report on comparable State and Territory data about cycling to provide a national perspective” and includes levels of bicycle usage and cyclist safety. Until this study is done, international benchmarking against international standards is not possible. (2) The National Strategy objective to include cycling expertise in peak transport, recreation and other bodies is an ongoing process. The Australian Bicycle Council has made substantial progress towards meeting this objective. (3) The National Strategy has succeeded in making available cycling education programs in most state and territories. However, the incorporation of education about cycling in school curriculums has not occurred in some jurisdictions such as Qld and SA because it is a matter of discretion for the school principals. (4) (a) The ABC membership includes representation from the bicycle industry wholesale and retail associations who provide ongoing engagement with the industry on developments and promotion of cycle products. The ABC also supports the Cycling Promotion Fund. (b) Work has been commenced under the National Strategy on a national data collection of all local government based actions associated with promoting and facilitating increased cycling activities. The ABC will use the information to evaluate the status of local government policy in relation to cycling issues, identify progress, and areas where further work is needed. (c) and (d) Significant progress has been made by state and territory governments to improve facilities for cyclists who use cycling for commuting to work and to increase multi-modal trips involving bicycles. Key examples include:
title: Notices

speaker: Mr Anderson
theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:In Perth and Fremantle bicycle lockers have been installed at railway stations; In Victoria there has been a review of the Principal Bicycle Network by VicRoads in partnership with Bicycle Victoria and local councils to ensure it remains an effective planning tool; In Tasmania $500,000 funding has been earmarked for improved cycle facilities throughout the state; In NSW a fully graded separated cycle way has been proposed along the Western Sydney Orbital road; In SA a new round of State Government funding has allocated $2m towards bicycle projects; and In the ACT the government has made a commitment to develop the Downer/Woden cycle link. (e) Work is being undertaken in separate jurisdictions to foster greater awareness of cyclists among all road users through various promotional programs and educational schemes. Key examples include: In WA the Balanced Transport System has been developed, with one of its objectives being to advise retailers, schools and local councils of cycle friendly policies and strategies; The ABC’s active role in supporting the Bicycling Australia Show; The establishment of the Bike Ed week and Cycle Instead campaigns in WA and Travel Smart Programme in SA; and The Safe Walking and Pedalling Programme in QLD. (f) Improving safety for cyclists is a high priority under the National Strategy. A number of initiatives have been established to ensure that cycling safety issues are considered in the identification of black spots, including: Commonwealth appointment of cyclist representatives to Black Spot community consultative panels in a number of states, and to Australian Transport Safety Bureau’s National Road Safety Strategy Panel; and The development of specific safety audits for cycling in QLD, TAS, NSW and the NT. (g) A number of jurisdictions are working to promote cycling awareness among motorists and other road users and improving safety on bicycle paths. Key examples include: The establishment of Share the Road educational campaigns in QLD, NSW and the ACT. The implementation of share path “behavioural signs” and guidelines for their use in Victoria. The Victorian Traffic Authority is also undertaking a trial of using coloured bicycle lanes to improve cyclist safety on major roads in Melbourne. Progress on the trial was reported at the last meeting of the Australian Bicycle Council on 15 March 2001. Australia Post: Street Posting Boxes (Question No. 306) Mr Kelvin Thomson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 14 May 2002: (1) How many street posting boxes have been removed by Australia Post since 1 January 2000 from the postcode areas of (a) 3130, (b) 3131, (c) 3132, (d) 3133, (e) 3134, (f) 3058, (g) 3056, (h) 3055, (i) 3057, (j) 3060, (k) 3044, (l) 3039 and (m) 3046. (2) What plans does Australia Post have to remove street posting boxes in the postcode areas of (a) 3130, (b) 3131, (c) 3132, (d) 3133, (e) 3134, (f) 3058, (g) 3056, (h) 3055, (i) 3057, (j) 3060, (k) 3044, (l) 3039 and (m) 3046 in the next 12 months. has provided the following answer, based on advice received from Australia Post, to the honourable member’s question: (1) Australia Post has not removed any street posting boxes from the 13 postcode areas listed since 1 January 2000.
title: Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the ArtsIt has relocated, upgraded and installed new street posting boxes within some of the postcode areas listed since 1 January 2000. Details are as follows: (a) 3130 – 2 boxes relocated; (b) 3131 – 2 boxes relocated and 1 new box installed; (c) 3132 – no change; (d) 3133 – no change; (e) 3134 – no change; (f) 3058 – 4 boxes relocated, 3 boxes upgraded, 3 boxes refurbished and 1 new box installed; (g) 3056 – no change; (h) 3055 – no change; (i) 3057 – no change; (j) 3060 – 3 boxes relocated; (k) 3044 – no change; (l) – no change and (m) 3046 – no change. (2) Australia Post does not have any plans to remove street posting boxes from the 13 postcode areas listed in the next 12 months. Telstra: Share Ownership (Question No. 431) Mr Pyne asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 28 May 2002: (1) Can the Minister provide a breakdown of the number of (a) T1 and (b) T2 Telstra shareholders in each federal electoral division. based on advice from Telstra, has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) No. Telstra has advised that the information relating to Telstra shareholders contained on the share registry that it is required to maintain under the requirements of the Corporations Act 2001, does not distinguish between shareholders that invested in T1 and T2. Telstra has also advised that the addresses of shareholders on its share register are not allocated according to federal electorates. Telstra has further advised that the release of information relating to its share register is only able to be undertaken in accordance with the Corporations Act.
title: Questions On Notice
